utterances: Absolutely, and I think, you know, following the change of policy of a few months ago, we're now getting far more stuff into Gaza, but we need to rehabilitate the infrastructure, rebuild homes there and at the same time, obviously, is doing everything we can to prevent weapons coming into Gaza because the enemy of this peace process are those people that, you know, right on the day we launched these peace negotiations, when I was at the White House with President Obama and other leaders there, they go out and they kill people in order to try and destabilize the process.

So I think we've got to improve the lives of people in Gaza whilst obviously taking the security measures in order to make sure those people who would use chaos and terrorism to thwart the process are denied that chance.
On Monday, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon called for a moratorium in Jewish settlements.
Can the talks move ahead without something like that or very much like that?
Well, it's a big challenge right now, and we're working hard to find a way through it.

I mean, the key thing on settlements is this: If you're going to negotiate an independent, viable, Palestinian state, then you obviously don't want anything happening in the meantime that prejudices the outcome of that negotiation.
So that's why the issue of settlements are important, and what we want to see is the idea of a reality on the ground developing consistent with the negotiation, not contradicting it.

Now I hope, Neal, in the discussion that will take place over the next few days that we'll find a way through this because we do, despite all the negativity around these talks, there is one great thing that we should bear in mind.
We have an American president that right from the outset of his term was determined to push the Middle East peace process.
We have two leaders that are now committed to the two-state solution.
We have two peoples that actually want that solution, and they've shown that consistently.
And we have a region that is not just tired of this struggle but actually recognizes the poison that goes into the whole of the region as a result of it and wants that poison removed.
a state of Israel that is secure and recognized by the whole of the region and a state of Palestine that is independent, sovereign and viable.
UNIDENTIFIED MAN #4: No, exactly.
This issue of the two-state solution and settlements is so perplexing.
How can a half a million Israelis live in Palestine with Palestine being a viable state?
Well, that's a good question, Ed, hello.
Of course, there's, you know, very much, very many more than that Israeli Arabs who live in Israel.
I think the issue is to decide the borders, and then we can decide what we do about the settlement question.
But, you know, this is an issue that has now, you know, dogged us for several years.
And I think the key thing we've got to do is to push ahead so that we resolve this notion of what the proper territory for the Palestinian state is.
And some of those settlements may remain, and they'll be swapped for land that will be given in exchange by Israel.
There may be other solutions that we find to this.
But if we leave this - the longer we leave it, and I think this is really what your question implies, the more difficult it's going to become.
So it's not impossible to have solutions to this, but it's hard to see how we're going to be able to do this if we don't get a solution reasonably soon.
Ed, thanks very much for the call, appreciate it.
And finally, Tony Blair, when you were prime minister, you attended a lot of these meetings, the general debates here at the United Nations.
What did you ever get out of it?
That's a very good question.
Look, the thing about these types of summits are to the outside world, they're just a whole lot of politicians talking.
But in the margins of the U.N.

meeting - I've just attended a meeting which is all about boosting the capacity of the Palestinians to build their state with major pledges of money and so on coming through peace negotiations going on at the same time.
And here's the other thing that happens at these summits, and it's interesting but true to reflect upon.
There is the formal process, right, the people you see on TV giving the speeches.
And, well, I mean, we can have an interesting debate about how much that achieves.

But outside in - you know, for your average leader, they will be meeting - you know, when I was here as a prime minister, I would maybe have 20 bilaterals with other leaders where you would be sorting out issues between your countries, issues that may be what to do with regional problems, and you would actually get a lot done.
So sometimes there's more going on in these things than meets the eye, at least I hope so.
At least we hope so.
And we hope you get a lot done at this meeting.
Good luck with your work.
Thank you very much indeed.
Thank you.
Tony Blair has an urgent meeting to attend, and we thank him for taking the time to speak with us.
Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair, with us from the U.N.
The book again: ""A Journey: My Political Life.
This September, 192 U.N.
member countries are gathered just down the street, all with their own agendas and their own plans for a week of speeches and meetings, news conferences and dinners.
The General Debate, as it's called, attracts President Obama, Iran's President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and dozens of others, but for what?
No votes will be recorded, no decisions made.
What actually gets done at this highest-profile meeting of world leaders?
Later in the hour, we'll talk with the former head of relief operations for the U.N.
who coordinated the response in Haiti and Pakistan.
But first, with all these leaders in town this week, what should get done?
Be specific please.
Email us, talk@npr.org.

Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Jan Eliasson has been on all sides of the General Assembly, served as its president in 2005, also as Sweden's ambassador to the U.N.
Now he's in town for the U.N.
meeting as the head of an NGO, the chair of WaterAid Sweden, an international group that focuses on safe water and sanitation in developing countries.
He has now taken Tony Blair's chair in Studio 5 in the U.N.
Nice to have you with us today.
Nice to be here.
And again, the same question that we opened - we closed with Tony Blair.
Some people have criticized this as a talking shop.
You've presided over it.
What actually gets done?
Well, Tony Blair underlined what is very important, that this is a meeting place.
Here's where you discuss a lot of serious issues also at the side.
But I think the meeting itself reminds us of how much we need to work together on today's global issues.
And there has to be a mobilization around the promises that were made.
We right now, today and the next two days, before the General Debate, will discuss if we fulfilled the so-called Millennium Goals on fighting poverty.
These promises were made in the year 2000, and it's a mixed bag in terms of results.
Therefore, it's good to have the leaders here, and now for me as a representative of civil society, to remind them of these promises and to see to it that they are fulfilled and achieved.
Well, we have to take a short break.

Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from New York City.

This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in New York City this week for the U.N.
General Assembly, and of course, world leaders have descended here for the annual meeting to take part in the global conversation.
Activists and advocates are here, too, in hopes of drawing attention to their cause.
This year, the agenda includes discussions about social development, food security, but among all the pomp, what actually gets done?
Come January, Republican Billy Long will represent Missouri's 7th Congressional District.
But before then, he's got work to do.
Today, we're talking about the U.N.
General Assembly, what's accomplished at the annual meetings.
We want to hear from you.
Tell us what you specifically think 192 world leaders should get done this week, 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation at our website.
That's at npr.org.
Click on TALK OF THE NATION.
And Jan Eliasson is with us, the former president of the General Assembly from the U.N., and you mentioned earlier, here working on clean water issues.
You're obviously here in New York at this meeting.
What are you actually getting done to advance that cause in this week?
Well, I was earlier also special envoy in Darfur for 18 months.
I was there, and I came back from that experience absolutely filled with the conviction that we have to move quicker on fulfilling the goals of water and sanitation.
Water is improving somewhat, but one of the most neglected areas of development is the lack of sanitation - to put it very simply, toilets.
Four thousand kids die every day.
And this is - the reason why this meeting is so important is that we have to remind the leaders to do better on this.
In some areas, there are progress, like child mortality and also literacy.
So there are some areas where there improvement.
But this is to check where we are on the different issues and remind them to move faster, particularly, I would say, on sanitation.
And how do you do that?
Do you hold meetings with these leaders?
Are you going to meet with President Obama?
Are you going to meet with the president of Sudan?

Well, we are going to listen to them now and hope to see, to hear commitments to do better on both development assistance, on trade and other issues that relate to development, and also from the developing countries, who have the problems, that they give higher priority to dealing with issues related to sanitation and health.
The beauty of doing this better on sanitation is that it has tremendously positive effects also on child mortality, maternal health, extreme poverty, gender equality.
These goals hang together, and that's...
And we know the value of the cause.
So do you.
But how do you communicate that to the people who actually make decisions?
Well, when a leader - I was also foreign minister of Sweden.
Yes, you were.
When you go to a meeting like this, you have to sort of say what do I have to bring, and what can I say about our development assistance?
Shall we stick to the zero-point percentage of aid of the GMP?
Shall we do more vis-a-vis this sector or another sector?
So the meeting itself is a place where you have to stand up to the promises made in the year 2000.
If we just made those promises 10 years ago and forgot about them, then we would probably have a very, very lacking achievement of the goals.
